content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Really interesting puzzle, nice for a clash of code. Non-trivial but still very reachable. Maybe it can be hard to solve it under 5 minutes but still possible with a bit of experience. I developed my own solution and the tests set is testing lot of possibilities. GG for your imagination!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This was fun, novel, and not too easy. It feels solvable in 5-10 minutes even in a lower-level language like C.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Difficult but multiple valid approaches exist and I think it's a good challenge/application!

Input / Constraints
* Please follow the example here to format the line numbers and variable names: https://www.codingame.com/playgrounds/40701/help-center/statement

Constraints
* Please reduce the upper limits of N and A_i, and increase the lower limit of A_i, so that they better reflect the actual ranges of values used in the cases.

Cases
* Each test and its corresponding validator (i.e. a pair of cases) should feature the SAME scenario with slightly different inputs. Please revise the cases accordingly.

Thanks.
I applied the recommended changes. Thank you!

Thank you for the update. A few things to adjust:

Goal
* In the example, the two 6s after the first fold make it a bit hard to tell which is which. Could you update the input so the folded values are distinct?

Constraints
* Please change 1 to 2, and 50 to 10.

* Please change -500 to -10, and 500 to 10.

Cases
* Validator 4: Please remove the trailing newline from the output.

* Please add a pair of new cases (i.e. Test 5 and Validator 5) where N = 10 and the array consists of totally random numbers (zero, negative and positive, a number may appear more than once).

Thanks.
